awd_titl_txt: Worker 4.0:  Preparing Students for Today's Technician Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
Missouri State University - West Plains will develop new advanced manufacturing curricula to address the workforce shortage in middle-skill industrial maintenance technicians. With a focus on advanced industrial maintenance, manufacturing, and alternative energy, the curriculum redesign will use stackable courses and a combination of project-based learning, hands-on computer simulations, and real laboratory environments to model the industrial workplace. Internships and registered apprenticeship opportunities with industry partners will build students' workforce readiness. The project will incorporate portions of the Greater Ozarks Center for Advanced Technology Fab Lab, the educational outreach component of the Massachusetts Institute for Technology's Center for Bits and Atoms, to engage a diverse group of students and interface with the community. Collectively, these activities will fill the gap for middle-skilled workers in the Industry 4.0 environment, which encompasses the computerization of manufacturing. The project will meet the regional need for qualified middle-skill advanced industrial maintenance and manufacturing technicians, and increase the enrollment in the technology certificates and associate of applied science in technology degree. 

The intellectual merit of Worker 4.0 includes adapting and adopting the Festo Industry 4.0 Certification Program (FI4.0CP), an industry recognized credential, into current technology courses, developing a new Advanced Industrial Maintenance Option in the A.A.S. in Technology degree, and developing a certificate that focuses on Advanced Industrial Maintenance. This includes creating three new courses: Introduction to Industry 4.0, Industrial Controls and Troubleshooting, and Programmable Logic Controllers and Sensors. Upon completion of the Advanced Industrial Maintenance Option in the A.A.S. in Technology degree or the Certification in Advanced Industrial Maintenance, the students will be prepared to complete the FI4.0CP Level 1: Fundamentals certification exam. Additionally, certified students will be able to continue their education with stackable FI4.0CP Level 2 and Level 3 courses and certifications. The broader impacts of Worker 4.0 include the dissemination of the curricular materials specifically developed for middle-skilled technicians in the next wave of an industrial transformation.

This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project was awarded in June 2019 and over the life of the grant, Missouri State University-West Plains (MSU-WP) has achieved better than anticipated outcomes.

  • MSU-WP became a National Coalition of Certification Centers (NC3) Leadership School, which allowed us to provide students the opportunity to obtain Festo Industry 4.0 Certifications, Lincoln Electric Fundamental and Advanced Certifications, Trane Data Analytics Certification, and Mike Rowe Works (MRW) Work Ethic Certification.  The University also became an American Welding Society (AWS) Educational Institution.
  • Students received a total of 138 certifications through the NC3 Festo Advanced Manufacturing program and the NC3 Lincoln Electric program.
  • Within the Associate of Applied Science (AAS) in Technology and technology-related certificate programs, there were a total of 33 students with a TEC major designation, a total of
  • 75 individuals instructed in 20 various courses, and 15 non-credit students in our manufacturing and machining program. The demographics of those students included 63 males, 12 females and 62 white, Black/African American, 2 American Indian, and 8 who identified as Multiple.
  • Nine students completed U.S. Department of Labor Registered Apprenticeships represented by two employer partner companies.
  • PI, Co-PI, faculty, and staff achieved 64 industry-recognized certifications through the NC3 train-the-trainer programs.
  • Created 12 new courses and modified 15 existing courses in the Technology program
  • Developed and refined the Associate of Applied Science (AAS) in Advanced Industrial Maintenance and a Certificate in Advanced Industrial Maintenance as a direct result of this project.
  • In addition to the AAS in Technology - Advanced Industrial Maintenance and Certificate in Advanced Industrial Maintenance, an AAS in Technology - Advanced Welding and Fabrication, Certificate in Advanced Welding & Fabrication, AAS in Technology -  Manufacturing Management, Certificate in Manufacturing Management, Certificate in Manufacturing & Technology Management, and Associate of Science (AS) in Engineering Technology ? Mechatronics were added at MSU-WP as a direct or indirect result of this project.
  • Raised awareness of the programs through outreach efforts to high school students, high school, personnel, and area industry
  • Disseminated results of this project through ATE PI Conferences, the ATE NSF One Page Reports, PowerPoint presentations and the related audio presentation at the 2019, 2020, and 2021 ATE PI Conferences.  The results of the Worker 4.0 project were also shared through the 2021 and 2022 ATE Surveys, the results of the Worker 4.0 project and during the five advisory board meetings between 2019 and 2022.
  • Served 15 area businesses throughout this project.  Industries served include Leonardo DRS; Jasper Engines and Transmissions; L & R Industries; CamCorp; Howell-Oregon Coop; City of West Plains; Royal Oak; Timberland Industries; Dairy Farmers of America; Eminence Manufacturing Inc. (EMI); Regal (no longer in business); Johnson Machine Works; ISF Racing; Perennial Energy; and Ozark Machinery.
  • Each of our industry partners has been actively participating in advisory board meetings, hiring, recruiting and training their incumbent workers, with two hosting a total of 9 student Registered Apprenticeships in the areas of Advanced Industrial Maintenance, Manufacturing Technicians, and Manufacturing Management.
  • This project set the stage for subsequent grants that allowed for further expansion of our technology-related programs.
  • During the project, MSU-WP received recognition from two organizations for outstanding work. In February 2020, we were nominated for the Bellwether Award for the Workforce Development Category. In 2021, our team received the Educator of the Year Award by the West Plains Chamber of Commerce. 

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2022
Modified by: Cathy P Boys
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project was awarded in June 2019 and over the life of the grant, Missouri State University-West Plains (MSU-WP) has achieved better than anticipated outcomes.

 MSU-WP became a National Coalition of Certification      Centers (NC3) Leadership School, which allowed us to provide students the      opportunity to obtain Festo Industry 4.0 Certifications, Lincoln Electric      Fundamental and Advanced Certifications, Trane Data Analytics      Certification, and Mike Rowe Works (MRW) Work Ethic Certification.  The University also became an American      Welding Society (AWS) Educational Institution.
 Students received a total of 138 certifications through the NC3 Festo Advanced Manufacturing program and the NC3 Lincoln Electric program.
Within the Associate of Applied Science (AAS) in Technology and technology-related certificate programs, there were a total of 33 students with a TEC major designation, a total of
75 individuals instructed in 20 various courses, and 15 non-credit students in our manufacturing and machining program. The demographics of those students included 63 males, 12 females and 62 white, Black/African American, 2 American Indian, and 8 who identified as Multiple.
Nine students completed U.S. Department of Labor Registered Apprenticeships represented by two employer partner companies.
PI, Co-PI, faculty, and staff achieved 64 industry-recognized certifications through the NC3 train-the-trainer programs.
Created 12 new courses and modified 15 existing courses in the Technology program
 Developed and refined the Associate of Applied Science      (AAS) in Advanced Industrial Maintenance and a Certificate in Advanced Industrial      Maintenance as a direct result of this project.
In addition to the AAS in Technology - Advanced Industrial      Maintenance and Certificate in Advanced Industrial Maintenance, an AAS in      Technology - Advanced Welding and Fabrication, Certificate in Advanced      Welding & Fabrication, AAS in Technology -  Manufacturing Management, Certificate in      Manufacturing Management, Certificate in Manufacturing & Technology Management,      and Associate of Science (AS) in Engineering Technology ? Mechatronics were      added at MSU-WP as a direct or indirect result of this project.
Raised awareness of the programs through outreach      efforts to high school students, high school, personnel, and area industry
 Disseminated results of this project through ATE PI      Conferences, the ATE NSF One Page Reports, PowerPoint presentations and      the related audio presentation at the 2019, 2020, and 2021 ATE PI      Conferences.  The results of the Worker      4.0 project were also shared through the 2021 and 2022 ATE Surveys, the      results of the Worker 4.0 project and during the five advisory board      meetings between 2019 and 2022.
Served 15 area businesses throughout this project.  Industries served include Leonardo DRS;      Jasper Engines and Transmissions; L & R Industries; CamCorp;      Howell-Oregon Coop; City of West Plains; Royal Oak; Timberland Industries;      Dairy Farmers of America; Eminence Manufacturing Inc. (EMI); Regal (no      longer in business); Johnson Machine Works; ISF Racing; Perennial Energy;      and Ozark Machinery.
Each of our industry partners has been actively      participating in advisory board meetings, hiring, recruiting and training      their incumbent workers, with two hosting a total of 9 student Registered      Apprenticeships in the areas of Advanced Industrial Maintenance,      Manufacturing Technicians, and Manufacturing Management.
This project set the stage for subsequent grants that      allowed for further expansion of our technology-related programs.
During the project, MSU-WP received recognition from      two organizations for outstanding work. In February 2020, we were      nominated for the Bellwether Award for the Workforce Development Category.      In 2021, our team received the Educator of the Year Award by the West      Plains Chamber of Commerce.
